thread.title: Chiefs defense comes up bit in win over Steelers
thread.title_full: Chiefs defense comes up bit in win over Steelers - KCTV5

author: Dave Eckert, Assignment Editor
title: Chiefs defense comes up bit in win over Steelers
text:
KANSAS CITY, MO (KCTV) - In desperate need of a win on Sunday, the Kansas City Chiefs defense stepped up in the turnover department and helped deliver one.
Relying on seasoned veterans, the Chiefs were able to keep Le’Veon Bell out of the end zone and force Landry Jones out of his comfort zone to lead the Chiefs to a 23-13 win.
The Chiefs trifecta of Tamba Hali, Derrick Johnson and Eric Berry were the heroes defensively, all of whom arrived prior to the John Dorsey/Andy Reid regime. Berry made his first interception of the year off pass Johnson deflected, and Hali forced the game-clinching fumble on a sack in the fourth quarter.
Johnson especially looked good on passing downs, as he too had an interception of his own coupled with numerous pass deflections and open field tackles. Both Johnson and Berry have been visibly slower at times this year, and still made mistakes this week, but the duos's play-making ability is still there and that’s a good sign for Kansas City moving forward.
Turnovers were really the key to the game, as Bell was able to run the ball well most of the time. The patient speedster totaled 121 yards on 17 carries, but was kept out of the end zone. This forced Jones to do more than manage the game for Pittsburgh, a tough task for someone making his first career NFL start.
At times, Jones looked poised in the pocket, especially on the 19-yard touchdown pass to Martavis Bryant. This was in part due to Kansas City’s inability to create much pressure. Jones only was hit once and sacked twice, all three times by Hali. However, Justin Houston did help in the run game along with Dee Ford, who had a key 4th down stop.
The pass defense was inconsistent at times, but was also tasked with covering some of the game’s best receivers. Antonio Brown turned in a 124-yard day as he rotated between corners Sean Smith and Marcus Peters for most of the day. Smith held his own with exception of one mistimed play, but Peters was often overmatched.
Peters has shown flashes of greatness this year, but also has flaws. The rookie’s run defense continues to be a major weakness as he was thrown down by Bell on one 3rd down run, and was often times turned around by the crafty Brown. He’ll need to be more physical at the line and let his speed recover against top receivers going forward.
The Chiefs were able to overcome numerous injuries coming in, as Ramik Wilson and Mike DeVito’s play was missed but not a crucial blow. Josh Mauga returned to inside line backer in Wilson’s spot, but was often times too slow for Pittsburgh’s backs. The Chiefs didn’t create as much pressure as they normally do with Devito in, as the Steelers were able to focus more on shutting down Allen Bailey and Jaye Howard.
Overall, the Chiefs defense did a commendable job of avoiding the backbreaking big play and limiting the mistakes. The D forced Jones to make big plays, and for the most part, he couldn't deliver. By keeping Brown and Bell out of the end zone they showed they can apply the bend but don’t break mentality to even the game’s best weapons.
They’ll need to have more of the same mindset next week, as they’ll be tasked to shut down Calvin Johnson, Jr. and the Detroit Lions in London.
Be ready to get your game on early. Kickoff is set for 8:30 a.m. central time.
